title: Introduction to Business English
learningObjectives: Understand basic business vocabulary and greetings
Learn the difference between formal and informal communication
Recognize common workplace terms and expressions

sections.title: Welcome to Business English
sections.content: Business English is the language used in professional settings like offices, meetings, and emails. It's more formal than everyday English and uses specific vocabulary. Learning business English will help you communicate professionally in the workplace and understand business conversations.

sections.title: Professional Greetings
sections.content: In business, we use formal greetings. Instead of 'Hi' or 'Hey', we say 'Good morning', 'Good afternoon', or 'Good evening'. When meeting someone for the first time, we say 'Nice to meet you' or 'Pleased to meet you'. We also use titles like Mr., Ms., or Dr. with last names to show respect.

sections.title: Common Workplace Words
sections.content: Every workplace has special words. An 'office' is where people work. A 'meeting' is when people talk about work together. A 'deadline' is the time when work must be finished. Your 'colleague' is someone who works with you. The 'manager' or 'boss' is the person who leads the team.

sections.title: Business Situations
sections.content:
Example 1: PROFESSIONAL GREETING - 'Good morning, Mr. Smith. I'm Maria. Nice to meet you.'

Example 2: IN A MEETING - 'We have a deadline next Friday. Can everyone finish by then?'

Example 3: EMAIL OPENING - 'Dear Ms. Johnson, I hope this email finds you well.'

Example 4: ASKING FOR HELP - 'Excuse me, could you please help me with this report?'

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content: Remember: Business English is formal and polite. Use proper greetings like 'Good morning' instead of 'Hi'. Learn workplace vocabulary like 'meeting', 'deadline', and 'colleague'. Always be respectful and professional in your communication. Practice makes perfect!

keyVocabulary.definition: A gathering of people to discuss work topics
keyVocabulary.example: We have a team meeting at 3 PM today.

keyVocabulary.definition: The time by which work must be completed
keyVocabulary.example: The deadline for this project is Friday.
My colleague helped me with the presentation.

keyVocabulary.definition: A person who leads and supervises a team
keyVocabulary.example: I need to speak with my manager about this.
I work in an office downtown.

keyVocabulary.definition: Electronic mail sent through the internet
keyVocabulary.example: Please send me an email with the details.

grammarPoints.explanation: In business, always use formal greetings. Say 'Good morning' instead of 'Hi' or 'Hey'. Use titles (Mr., Ms., Dr.) with last names.
examples: Formal: Good morning, Mr. Smith. How are you today?
commonMistakes: Forgetting to use titles with last names
Being too casual in first meetings

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Could you please...' or 'Would you mind...' to make polite requests in business settings.
examples: Could you please send me the report?
Would you mind helping me with this?
May I ask you a question?
commonMistakes: Using 'Give me...' instead of 'Could you please give me...'
